mxCell.value:
It is important to understand the relationship between production grade devops workflow and docker

Its possible to have a devops workflow without using docker

But using docker as a tool in this workflow we can make some of task log easier

diagram.name: 06 - build image from docker file with custom name

mxCell.value:
Docker volumes can be use to automatically propated changes done to our source code to Container without rebuilding it

Docker volume kinda similer to port mapping where reference created on container file sysytem the way container can access local directory file system.

Setting up docker volume is bit user unfriendly due to long docker command.

pwd only work with linux or git bash not working with powershell
Map the current working directory (pwd) to the '/app' folder

Put a bookmark on the node_modules folder inside the container's FS
(This one only need when we dont have node_modules folder inside our working directory)

diagram.name: 09 - Volumes and live updating tests with Docker Compose

mxCell.value:
version: '3'
services:
  web:
    build:
      context: .
      dockerfile: Dockerfile.dev
    ports:
      - "3000:3000"
    volumes:
      - /app/node_modules
      - .:/app
  tests:
    build:
      context: .
      dockerfile: Dockerfile.dev
    volumes:
      - /app/node_modules
      - .:/app
    command: ["npm", "run", "test"]

How to force docker-compose CLI to build image from docker file with custom name.

In here if dockerfile located in folder within the working directory we can add that folder name instead of .

3) Add 2nd service to docker-compose file for testing. This 2nd service totally identical to 1st one excepts the last line where default startup command (npm run start) of Dockerfile.dev has override by npm run test

1) Running test with docker CLI commands (but with this way it always needed to rebuild docker when App.test.js file changes due to adding new tests or otherwise we need to set a volume in dockerfile for live updating tests)


Docker build -f dockerfile.dev
Docker run -it <image-id> npm run test

To run test on already running container we can use this command without rerunning it (in this case also if we have setup volumes in docker-compose.yml file updates in App.test.js will live reflect in the container)

Docker exec -it <container-id> npm run test

2) Running test with docker-compose CLI commands in simplier way

Docker-compose up
Docker ps
get container id
Docker exec -it <container-id> npm run test

Downside of 1) and 2) methods is we need to build image and then separatly need to run test command.

Downside of 3) methods is we can't re-run test by clicking enter and we can't get the custom test like in method 1) and 2) by clicking shortcut key like q, p and w.
Test Container
Web Container

docker attach <docker-id>
using this command we only can attached to process id 1 (root) process only

• But process test.js is the process that should give response to test minipulations
  • stdin stdout and stderr is process oriented
  • Linux commands to check running process is ps and ones we enter to container shell using docker exec -it <container-id> sh also we can use ps to check all the running process on the container
Web Container
Web Container
Production servers (nginx) sole purpose to accpet in coming requrest and respond to them

Development server should have high amount of hardware resource to process and serve js files to broswer.

But ones we move to producation environment this falls away. Instend we run npm run build to get final index.html and main.js files.

In order to communicate this two files to user broswer we need to have producation server.

But for this producation server we dont need lot of hardware resources since we dont need to process js and html files ones we setup producation env. All we need to serve files to user broswer

version: '3'
services:
  web:
    build:
      context: .
      dockerfile: Dockerfile.dev
    ports:
      - "3000:3000"
    volumes:
      - /app/node_modules
      - .:/app
  tests:
    build:
      context: .
      dockerfile: Dockerfile.dev
    volumes:
      - /app/node_modules
      - .:/app
    command: ["npm", "run", "test"]

FROM node:alpine as builder
WORKDIR '/app'
COPY package*.json ./
RUN npm install
COPY . .
RUN npm run build

FROM nginx
EXPOSE 80
COPY --from=builder /app/build /usr/share/nginx/html

FROM node:alpine

WORKDIR '/app'

COPY package.json .
RUN npm install

COPY . .

CMD ["npm", "run", "start"]
